body:
### Description

When working in a project which uses Yarn2 (also known as PnP or Plug and Play) and then opening a for example a `.js` file, the ESLint LSP tries to start but can't, printing this warning:
```
[lspconfig] Unable to find ESLint library.
```

When using Yarn2, the eslint executable is not `node_modules` but instead in `.yarn/sdks`. 

This can be fixed by hardcoding the following setting:
```lua
vim.lsp.config('eslint', {
  settings = { nodePath = '.yarn/sdks' },
})
```

That is an okay solution, but not good if working in a multiple projects where some use Yarn2 and some use npm. It would be great if the config could detect if Yarn2 or something else is used and set the `nodePath` according to that.

When looking in the [eslint.lua](https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/blob/943a0556638fb809d3f72f1f091454bd56b23021/lsp/eslint.lua#L151) in this repo, it seems there is a solution for that, but it's not working (at least not for me). 

I tried the following but that did not work either.
```lua    
vim.lsp.config('eslint', {
  settings = { nodePath = 'node_modules' },
  before_init = function(_params, config)
    local yarn_lib = vim.fs.find('.yarn/sdks/eslint', { path = config.root_dir, upward = true })[1]
    if yarn_lib then
      config.settings.nodePath = '.yarn/sdks'
    end
  end
})
```

Does anyone have an idea on another solution for this? Could this be done?
title: Unable to find ESLint library when using Yarn2 (PnP)
